Though I enjoyed the book and dvd, there are a few quirks that have set a number of social anthropologists off - things like stating that some cultures are somehow more primitive or less civilized. I think there was a little bit of unconscious channeling of the mode of talk of the time (late 60s, early 70s) and perhaps an unfortunate choice of words. If you can suspend the inevitable cringe at those moments then the series is really a very enjoyable and informative one. And there are some real period gems- the computer keyboard with its clunky switches and flickering green screen, the 'advanced' graphics etc., which of course were the pre-cursors for the media we take so much for granted as part of our everyday life today. I found most of the programmes a joy to watch and the chapters a joy to read, especially the debates around little 'Lucy's' skull and all the paleoanthropological stuff - the book is very much a helpful accompaniment to the television series.

Often described as one of the classics of our times, this is a book of essays charting the various stages in the author's conception of the intellectual evolution of humanity. In a sense it should be compared to Civilisation, Kenneth Clarke's history of art: a personal selection of important events.Bronowski's is a selection few would argue with, but he adds interest through his own personal acquaintanceship with some of the characters involved: Einstein, Born, and (most interestingly) von Neumann. His take on early history had probably been overtaken by some of modern anthropology, but his analysis of the industrial revolution is fascinating, as is his central thesis that the main agent of progress is simply the desire of the craftsman to improve his craft, beyond any real pressure for improvement coming from outside.

I never thought I would say this, but I'm in love with a tiny scientist who is, unfortunately, dead. The Ascent of man is a compilation of Bronowski's essays on the evolution of man and science featured in his incredible BBC series of the same name. I watched the episodes at night and then re-read the essays on the following day for a complete immersion. The series came out in the early 70s but it still feels fresh. If you're looking for a great history of science this is it! Bronowski's family came to England from Germany shortly after WWI and he learned to speak english at the same time he started learning chemistry. This happy coincidence somehow gave him the unique ability to express scientific ideas in the most poetic way. "The hand is the cutting edge of the mind," says Bronowski. Amen, brother. If you can't read this book, watch the series. If you can't watch the series, read this book. Ideally, do both!

I must admit my scientific schooling ended at O level physics and chemistry some 30 years ago and there were times when the book (as an expanded script from the acclaimed television series) cried out for the visuals that would have accompanied it originally as an aid to my understanding.What I appreciated most was Bronowski's placing of science at the heart of human history without dismissing art. Indeed he is very much at pains to acknowledge the special way that art and creativity interacts with scientific thought and discovery.It's a useful primer in the major discoveries and developments in science and a powerful plea for tolerance, openess and dialogue as not only essentials for further scientific progress but also for the well-being and development of our species and culture.A much-respected book but maybe time is beginning to tell on it after 40+ years in print with some out-of-date views on ethnography (opening chapters) and Zen Buddhism (in the closing chapter).

"Man is not unique because he does science, and not because he does art, but because science and art are expressions of his marvellous plasticity of mind"This is really good book, with many historical and other lines of thought drawing upon the main theme of the book, The Ascent of Man, Very deep in many ways, cultural, social, scientific development, mental development, inventions, industrial, medical, and other improvements in quality of life, leading to how we live today, and why, The historical references are excellent, and they are theme based, and not based purely on historical fact, so it is a much more deep reading than having to read just a plain 'history book' with just facts in chronological order, Quote from the book: "The personal commitment of a man to his skill, the intellectual commitment and the emotional commitment working together as one, has made the Ascent of Man"Good Book!Highly Recommended Reading,

Last year, for the 50th anniversary of the publication of Rachel Carlson's Silent Spring, New Scientist magazine came up with a list of the top 25 most influential popular science books for readers to vote on for the top 10. This made the cut at #10, and for my money, should have been a lot higher. At least higher than Gaia.Despite being published in 1976, it stands the test of time. A few things are negated by recent discoveries, but in general, Bronowski's book tells a great story. "We are nature's unique experiment to make the rational intelligence prove itself sounder than the reflex. Knowledge is our destiny"I'd say the "unique" is "so far", but concur with the destiny.Good stuff. Recommended

As a scientist,I find this book phenomenal! Bronowski is an intellect with a great way of telling you about human history and describe how humans have "ascended". He connects sciences, art, philosophy, history, and many more together, making the book on human history an interesting read. Bronowski paints a historic picture, and expresses scientific and philosophical ideas in the most poetic way. This book puts you on a journey of human development in several fields around the world.5 stars for the book. Still have to watch the series.Conclusion:I would recommend this book to everyone, young or old. We learn from our history books, and this is the perfect book to summarize all the greatest human achievements and scientific developments. You would appreciate how far we have reached, and may think how, in this connected world, much we may achieve.

Ascent of Man the book is really just Ascent of Man the television series in book form. As such, I can only give if 4 of 5 stars. The book and series together easily earn 5 of 5 stars. Ascent of Man is a deeply personal look at the history of man’s advancement from the dawn of time up until modern times. Though reading the book—and even more so watching the series—is a bit of a time warp, both having been created in the early 1970s, it is still worthwhile. Bronowski’s repeated message is that humans have great potential but equally great responsibility, and that the bedrock of any advancement is the acknowledgement that there is still much to learn. “There is no absolute knowledge. And those who claim it, whether they are scientists or dogmatists, open the door to tragedy (p. 353).”

This is basically an abridged urdu translation of "The ascent of man "by J. Bronwski ,translated by Mansur Saeed , fiction House Lahore,Pakistan.The author follows the evolution of man through the era of pre homo-erectus ,peking man ,homosapiens ,ica age ,pastoral and agricultural revolution,introduction of wheel and pully ,hanging gardens of babylone,greek geometry, Arabic algebra, marchant of venice ,vatican censors, theory of relativity, Quantun physics ,genetics DNA, Cloning , and finally computers. Its a scholorly narration of human ascendancy in a romantic style through the ages and needs to be read again and again.

I picked a copy of this up on the strength of the recommendations made by David Deutsch in his "The Beginning Of Infinity" book.It is basically a potted history of human innovation from prehistory and the developement of bronze and iron to genetics and game theory. I found his explanations where clear and thorough and far surpassed those of more recent authors such as Richard Dawkins and Matt Ridley when it came to biology and evolutionary theory, although at times the prose was a little convoluted,particularly in the early chapters.As for the question "is it still relevant?" I'd say 90% of it is still correct the major changes being in the early chapters on the origins of our species.

There is no such thing as maturity. He gives no real life evidence for the anti-young definition of maturity he gives when discussing Hamlet, who you need to remember was fictional!His description of the bleak life of the transhumance travelling lifestyle, illustrated by Bakhtiari nomada in Iran, is very affecting, and angering that anyone would accept that life. You so want them to get out of it. It makes you more prepared to listen to his old fashioned Western leaning view of the cultures condusive to scientific advances. He confronts us with, why did 2 unconnected men in the same country and era discover evolution? It's a striking thought.

Well, I'm coming to this one mighty late, but what a pleasure it is. It has huge sweep: the whole of human history. And it focuses on some of the things that make us human. What's fascinating is that to my mind Bronwoski focuses on an attribute that others rarely do: our aesthetic sense. He suggests that this underpins, even reconciles, our artistic, scientific and technological endeavours. If there's a criticism, it's that the book is too close to the original TV script. The problem is not that this makes the tone informal; the problem is that visual references fail, which undermines some of the exposition.

A fascinating series of essays on the development of humankind in both cultural and technological aspects, absolutely guaranteed to make you think about humanity's past and present in entirely new ways. It clearly does, however, hearken from an earlier era in which humanity was believed to be progressing towards something, an idea which nowadays is less commonly held. I personally was quite charmed by this very 70s sensibility - I almost felt myself being whisked back in time to my childhood of watching PBS on the old black-and-white, feeling utterly engaged with human history. Very well worth reading - I highly recommend it.http://lorilschafer.blogspot.com

Amazing and inspiring insights, Bronowski expresses a beautiful world view. I only wish this was something I would have experienced when I was very young, or could have walked with him and chatted on that same San Diego beach that I recognize so well.I highly recommend watching the series alongside reading the book; there's a remarkable charm to this man, and once you see even one episode it becomes difficult to read the book without hearing his voice... with those lovely rolling r's and the impassioned tone matched only by his wild gesticulations.

“... the blue glow that is the trace of neutrons: the visible finger of God touching Adam in Michelangelo’s painting, not with breath but with power.”"The Ascent of Man" is a short and sweeping account of the rise of civilization told through the prism of science. Bronowski marries impressive depth and breadth of knowledge with strong literary chops; his writing style is consistently engaging and every page is sprinkled with pithy turns of phrase. That being said, I did find the first half stronger and it lost a bit of steam towards the modern era. But overall, highly recommended.

It's hard to imagine how someone could cover 12,000 years of man's history in 450 pages, but Bronowski does so in an amazing book documenting history's greatest inventors and man's most important achievements. Makes you realize how extremely unlikely it is that we are even here on this planet and what a miracle it is that we can share it with all of the species that exist today. Excellent theories on what led the migrations to certain parts of the earth and when they occurred. Worth reading - you will surely learn something.

In his own words:"...With dogma and ignorance he brooked no rebuttal." Jacob BronowskiBronowski is referring to Bishop Ussher in this quote... Talk about the pot calling the kettle black!Speaking of black... Black people are completely ignored is this series as if they were simply some obscure species of ape having no direct relation to man.A choice Bronowskism: "Think of the investment that evolution has made in the child's brain."?! Evolution anthropomorphized? Yes, indeed, and making investments!

This book is a perfect example of how far we have come as humans. The science isn’t perfect admittedly, and that’s largely because this was written nearly 40 years ago, but it’s fascinating to see how far our research has progressed over those 40 years, and since the beginning of human life.It was written to accompany the TV series and is set out in 13 short essays all on different topics. I liked the format as each essay was a good length to read with a coffee!

After a ridiculous narrative of the history of 50 million years from six skull fragments (including the long-discredited Ramapithecus), this becomes a fun history. Bronowski's celebration of man's achievements can better be appreciated when we understand them to be God's image bearers. The author surprisingly questions his whole project after visiting the ash-strewn marshes surrounding Aushwitz.

Three book that fits into my wall-of-fame of popular science book.1. Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies2. Cosmos3. and this one.If you want to understand how human are placed into the history, read those three books.

I've rated this five stars and as one of my Favourites but this review really applies to the thirteen-part BBC TV series written and hosted by Jacob Bronowski that was first aired in 1973. It was outstanding and worth tracking down on DVD or from your library. The book is really just an accompaniment to the TV series. It's fine but can't replace watching the original (if you can handle the bizarre theme music).

This is, in fact, merely the transcript of the television show. Having said that let me say it is one of the best books I have every read and one of the few I have read several times. Every paragraph is full of fascinating information about the way in which humans have learned about the universe from galaxies to the atom. It always took me a while to read because I would constantly find myself stopping to think about what I had just read.

This book was written in conjunction with a television series and to have combined the two would have made it more interesting. Having just read Sapiens which I thought covered the history of mankind much better. The knowledge gained since this book has been written would also have helped to give a better understanding of how we have arrived at where we are. However the book was very interesting and added a bit more to my understanding of human kind.

I fell in love with this book during my college days. The UP Main Lib was my home on Saturdays and it was here where I discovered Bronowski's great writing... A very scholarly yet highly readable exposition of the history of man. Many years later, serendipity led me to an obscure book sale and I stumbled upon an unused hardbound copy that now graces my library.

An excellent book if you are looking for an overview of humanity. I really wish the documentary series on which it is based was available in a decent format. From what I understand, it is better simply because of the visuals and Bronowski's energy while he was actually in the places of which he spoke. Overall though, fantastic.

I have read this book a dozen times since it was published and Dr. Bronowski continues to inspire me with his impassioned history of man's intellectual evolution. Of course, the study of history and of man has advanced since 1976, but this man's writing can still save me when my pessimism about our progress threatens to overwhelm me.

The Ascent of Man is an amazing book. It has great insights into how we've evolved as humans. I was fascinated by a part in the book that stated that the Arab world forbade the study of human anatomy. How advanced would the field of medicine have been had such a prohibition not existed? The book is meant to spark curiosity and wonder, two things that we don't encourage enough in today's world.

This polymath really gives you an overview of progress. His hard hitting opinions may cause you to disagree but his passion makes you want to read more. In his life he studied the effects of the atomic bomb in Nagasaki and made friends with many important scientists, writers and artists.An optimistic humanist and a committed intellectual he makes learning intriguing!

This is a discursive but engaging, informative, and illustrative intellectual and cultural history. It is particularly engaging and informative given the confused and invalid cultural milieu of the twentieth century, which the author largely reflects. He saw that the collapse of Western civilization was well on its way in 1973. The final chapter is titled "The Long Childhood".

I mostly enjoyed reading the book. A few pages in the last chapter are racist with some sweeping generalizations of Eastern Civilizations mixed with a dash of notions of White Man's Burden. All along I assumed "we" meant humanity, I wasn't sure after the last chapter. Bronowski's "we" means only the Western Civilization. Maybe the book must be titled appropriately to reflect this.

Interesting history of man that traces his progress through developments in science. A few cool insights (e.g. a fascinating description of relativity) but overall a rather dogmatic treatment of the subject.

The Ascent of Man by Jacob Bronkowski (Little, Brown and Co. 1973) (501) is the book form of the narration that accompanied the television series "The Ascent of Man" on PBS. This explores man from ape to the space age. It's a great read. My rating: 7.5/10, finished 1987.

The most inspiring read. Shows how you can be amazed at and proud of the human condition and awe inspired at our past and at the potential for further cultural "evolution". Read 3 times now and each time it fills me with a sense of purpose & worth. Better than any religous tome.
I remember the series only vaguely: couldn't have been more than 10 or so during its first run. Today the Guardian published this article to mark the re-issue of the book. Sounds marvellous.

"The personal commitment of a man to his skill, the intellectual commitment and the emotional commitment working together as one, has made the Ascent of Man."Amazing book, very cool. Saw the series as a kid, now finally got to read the book.

This was a difficult read. I don't think I was in the right mindset to start delving into it. It's not necessarily the matter that was complex or challenging, it was just the ridiculous set-up to the whole text. It read like I should have watched it on television. Oh. Wait.

The ASCENT OF MAN remains as fresh and relevant as the day it was first published.For seekers asking the question, What makes us human?"; Jacob Bronowski stands as a hero in the most authentic sense."......we have to touch...people....."

This book was part of the prize I received in 1972 from the British Broadcasting Corporation's short story competition. I still read it and find it useful. I can always find a quotation from this book to support my arguments whenever I have to give a lecture.

'The'book if you want to know how our species went from being a bunch of ragged hunters to the intrepid space explorers. The book not only tells us about the technological innovations but how our thinking changed and keeps changing as time proceeds.

This book is as great read. It has one major flaw. Since it is a transcription of the video documentary into book form, one finds it difficult to grasp the concepts without the scenery and visual demonstrations Dr. Bronowski so adeptly employs to illuminate his ideas.

Read this in 1973. Transformative. Changed my career aspirations and my life. Bronowski is so passionate about science as a vehicle for improving the human condition. I watched the TV series about the same time (or just before reading), so that probably enhanced the experience.

This book was a real slog for me. Occasional interesting tidbits about the history of science are interspersed among a fair amount of speculative and frankly Whiggish readings of scientific developments in 20th century etc and the people who made them.
Amazing book, really shaped my way of thinking when I was growing up. Great insights into the development of our collective intellect.
i watched the whole documentary series long ago and bought the book, gotta read it at some point/
a classic, he creates fascinating connections between art, history art, architecture and philosophy, part of the reason why I studied anthropology. Can't be an intellectual, if you skipped this one.
Good, but kind of like the script for a very dry PBS special. I think it may have been a book released in association with the BBC or something?
Excellent read for anyone transfixed by sources and directions within patterns of the history that we call human.
Originally saw it as a mini-series on TV with Bronowski himself doing the narration. Got the book as a Christmas present in 1976. Reading it as a teenage changed much of thinking as an adult.
Incredible bit of work that still stand up.
The material in this book is a touch out of date but it is still a nice overview of many fields of study. It's a pretty light read so if that sort of thing interests you why not check it out.
I read this about 35 years ago and thought it was time to re-read; and so it was indeed. If you can get the video, that would be very good(especially given all the visuals referred to)."
this is one of the most important and the best books FOREVER and EVER.
An engaging Western perspective on humanity's exploration of the natural world. Re-presents the eponymous BBC television series.
This book really explains the complementary nature of Arts and Sciences. It's pretty deep, timeless and at time poignant.
I like the chapters on physics and the last essay the best.
Have been watching the series and reading chapters of this as I went. Such a good series. The book is more or less the same as the recording. The photographs/illustrations seemed to lack a bit.
Will read based on Dick Edwards' review.
I thought this was very good indeed, and the television series remains a gold standard against which documentaries are compared and contrasted.
One of my favorite books...
Wanted to read this for a while now.
Bronowski offers great insight into the powerful meaning of many myths and of our lives.
One of the best Christmas presents I have ever received albeit a very long time ago.
Still valid, and while much more has been learned since this gem was published, it's a must-read for anyone interested in the field.
The companion book to the 70s documentary. Feels a bit dated. Especially the ancient computer graphics. I remember enjoying the documentary quite a bit but this seems disorganized and poorly edited.
Re-read actually. First time in many years. There is always something new to find.Am joyfully glad to be reminded of the poem by Donne quoted on page 406...
A pretty decent history of mankind, with an emphasis on science. Not nearly as enjoyable as Sagan's Cosmos, but it presented similar information from a slightly different perspective.
I read the 2012 Folio edition. An excellent book, extremely readable and written for the non-expert. Very stimulating throughout.
Short and great summary of the history of humanity. Here is my blog post on this reading: https://carmenrodrigueza.wordpress.co...
Excellent journey through history from a scientific and humanistic point of view.
